question.text: What share of global energy will come from renewable sources in 2050?

config.context: Current renewable share: ~15% (2024). Paris targets: 60-70% by 2050. Key uncertainties: policy ambition, battery/storage costs, grid infrastructure, fossil fuel phase-out pace, nuclear expansion.

uncertainties.name: Battery Cost Decline
uncertainties.description: How rapidly will battery storage costs fall and grid-scale storage become economically viable. This determines whether intermittent renewables can reliably replace baseload fossil fuels.
uncertainties.search_query: battery storage costs 2030 grid scale lithium ion price decline renewable energy storage

uncertainties.name: Policy Implementation Strength
uncertainties.description: Whether governments will actually implement and maintain aggressive renewable energy policies, subsidies, and fossil fuel restrictions through 2050. This includes both domestic policies and international coordination.
uncertainties.search_query: renewable energy policy implementation carbon pricing fossil fuel subsidies climate targets 2030

uncertainties.name: Nuclear Renaissance Scale
uncertainties.description: The extent to which nuclear power will expand as a clean baseload alternative to fossil fuels. Nuclear could either complement renewables or compete with them for the non-fossil energy share.
uncertainties.search_query: nuclear power expansion 2030 small modular reactors new nuclear plants construction clean energy

signals.text: By December 31, 2027, lithium-ion battery pack costs fall below $50/kWh according to BloombergNEF's annual battery price survey
signals.reasoning: Battery costs below $50/kWh are considered the threshold for grid-scale storage to become economically competitive with fossil fuel peaker plants. This price point would make intermittent renewables viable as baseload power replacements.

signals.text: By June 30, 2028, at least 100 GWh of new grid-scale battery storage capacity is deployed globally in a single year, per IEA Energy Storage Report
signals.reasoning: Massive deployment demonstrates that battery storage has reached economic viability and scale. 100 GWh represents a tipping point where storage can meaningfully stabilize grids with high renewable penetration.

signals.text: Before January 1, 2029, Tesla's 4680 battery cells achieve manufacturing costs below $60/kWh as reported in Tesla's quarterly earnings calls
signals.reasoning: Tesla's 4680 technology represents next-generation battery manufacturing. If they achieve sub-$60/kWh costs, it signals that advanced manufacturing techniques can drive dramatic cost reductions across the industry.

signals.text: By December 31, 2026, QuantumScape or another solid-state battery company begins commercial production of >1 GWh annually, per company press releases
signals.reasoning: Solid-state batteries promise higher energy density and lower costs than lithium-ion. Commercial production would signal a technology breakthrough that could accelerate battery cost declines beyond current projections.

signals.text: By December 31, 2027, China announces domestic battery storage installations exceeding 50 GW cumulative capacity, per National Energy Administration data
signals.reasoning: China drives global battery manufacturing scale. Massive domestic deployment would demonstrate economic viability and drive manufacturing volumes that reduce costs globally through economies of scale.

signals.text: Before July 1, 2028, lithium carbonate prices fall below $15,000/ton and remain there for 6 consecutive months, per Benchmark Mineral Intelligence
signals.reasoning: Raw material costs are a major component of battery prices. Sustained low lithium prices would remove a key constraint on battery cost reduction and signal adequate supply chain scaling.

signals.text: By December 31, 2026, at least 5 major utilities announce grid-scale battery storage projects exceeding 1 GWh each, per utility regulatory filings
signals.reasoning: Utility-scale adoption indicates that storage economics have reached the point where conservative utility companies view batteries as cost-effective investments for grid stability and renewable integration.

signals.text: Before January 1, 2028, CATL or BYD announces battery cell manufacturing costs below $40/kWh for their latest chemistry, per company investor presentations
signals.reasoning: Chinese manufacturers lead global battery production. If top producers achieve $40/kWh costs, it demonstrates manufacturing scale effects and process improvements that would rapidly spread industry-wide.

signals.text: By June 30, 2027, iron-phosphate (LFP) batteries achieve energy density exceeding 200 Wh/kg in commercial products, per manufacturer specifications
signals.reasoning: LFP batteries are cheaper but less energy-dense than other chemistries. Improved energy density while maintaining cost advantages would make them suitable for more grid applications, accelerating adoption.

signals.text: Before December 31, 2028, the US DOE announces battery manufacturing tax credits have triggered over $50 billion in new domestic factory investments, per DOE press releases
signals.reasoning: Massive manufacturing investment signals confidence in battery demand growth and would create competition that drives costs down. Geographic diversification also reduces supply chain risks for battery adoption.

signals.text: By December 2026, the US passes federal legislation mandating >50% renewable electricity by 2035, with binding state-level targets and penalties >$1B for non-compliance, per Congressional Budget Office scoring
signals.reasoning: Federal mandates with strong enforcement mechanisms are crucial for policy implementation strength. The US is a major energy consumer, so aggressive federal action would signal high implementation likelihood globally and demonstrate political feasibility of binding targets.

signals.text: By June 2027, China's National Development and Reform Commission announces >$200B in additional renewable energy subsidies for 2027-2030, representing >50% increase from 2023-2026 levels
signals.reasoning: China is the world's largest energy consumer and CO2 emitter. Sustained, increased subsidy commitments beyond current plans would strongly indicate policy implementation strength and long-term government commitment to renewables transition.

signals.text: By December 2025, the EU Carbon Border Adjustment Mechanism covers >80% of global trade value in steel, cement, aluminum, and chemicals, with tariffs averaging >$100/tonne CO2, per European Commission data
signals.reasoning: Successful implementation of carbon border adjustments demonstrates willingness to use trade policy for climate goals and creates international pressure for decarbonization. Broad coverage and high tariffs indicate strong policy implementation.

signals.text: By January 2028, >15 countries representing >40% of global GDP have eliminated fossil fuel subsidies worth >$50B annually combined, per OECD verification
signals.reasoning: Eliminating fossil fuel subsidies is politically difficult but crucial for renewable competitiveness. Widespread subsidy removal would demonstrate exceptional policy implementation strength and commitment to market-based renewable transitions.

signals.text: By December 2026, >30 countries commit to phasing out coal power by 2035 with binding timelines and >$500B in transition financing secured, per COP30 official agreements
signals.reasoning: Coal phase-out commitments with concrete timelines and financing demonstrate serious policy implementation. International coordination on binding targets would indicate strong multilateral policy implementation capability.

signals.text: By June 2027, the International Monetary Fund conditions >$100B in lending to developing nations on achieving specific renewable energy deployment targets verified by independent monitors
signals.reasoning: IMF conditional lending creates powerful implementation incentives for developing countries where much future energy growth will occur. This would indicate international financial institutions are enforcing renewable transitions through policy conditionality.

signals.text: By December 2025, >10 major oil companies face successful shareholder resolutions mandating >50% capex shift to renewables by 2030, with binding board commitments per SEC filings
signals.reasoning: Corporate governance changes forcing oil companies to pivot indicate that policy and market pressure is successfully compelling private sector implementation. This suggests policy frameworks are creating effective incentive structures.

signals.text: By January 2028, global renewable energy investment reaches >$3 trillion annually with >70% coming from government-backed sources, per International Energy Agency tracking
signals.reasoning: Government-backed investment at massive scale would demonstrate unprecedented policy implementation strength. This level of sustained public investment would indicate governments are putting substantial resources behind renewable policies.

signals.text: By December 2026, >20 US states implement renewable portfolio standards requiring >80% clean electricity by 2040, with aggregate penalties for non-compliance exceeding $10B annually
signals.reasoning: State-level policy implementation with strong enforcement demonstrates policy durability across political cycles. High penalty levels indicate serious commitment to implementation rather than symbolic targets.

signals.text: By June 2027, the G20 establishes a binding international carbon price floor of >$75/tonne with enforcement mechanisms and >$500B in compliance funding, per official G20 communique
signals.reasoning: International coordination on carbon pricing with enforcement represents the strongest possible signal of policy implementation strength. A binding global framework would indicate unprecedented international cooperation on climate policy.

signals.text: By December 2027, at least 10 countries announce new nuclear power plant construction projects totaling >50 GW capacity, per IAEA World Nuclear Status Report
signals.reasoning: A wave of new nuclear commitments would signal strong political and economic momentum behind nuclear expansion, directly indicating the scale of the nuclear renaissance and its potential to compete with renewables for clean energy market share by 2050.

signals.text: Before January 2029, at least one Small Modular Reactor (SMR) design receives full commercial operating license from either NRC, CNS, or equivalent EU regulator
signals.reasoning: SMR commercialization is critical for nuclear renaissance as it promises lower costs, faster deployment, and enhanced safety. Success here would dramatically change nuclear's competitive position against renewables and accelerate adoption timelines.

signals.text: By end of 2026, global nuclear construction pipeline exceeds 200 GW in capacity under construction or final planning stages, per World Nuclear Association annual report
signals.reasoning: The size of the construction pipeline is a leading indicator of nuclear's trajectory. 200+ GW would represent a massive scaling beyond current ~60 GW under construction, signaling a true renaissance that could materially impact 2050 energy mix.

signals.text: Before December 2028, nuclear power costs fall below $80/MWh LCOE for new plants in at least 3 major economies, per IEA World Energy Outlook or equivalent analysis
signals.reasoning: Cost competitiveness is the key factor determining whether nuclear can scale alongside or instead of renewables. Achieving sub-$80/MWh would make nuclear highly competitive with solar/wind plus storage in many markets.

signals.text: By January 2027, China completes construction of >20 GW of new nuclear capacity compared to 2024 baseline, per official government energy statistics
signals.reasoning: China is the world's largest energy market and has the manufacturing capacity to drive global nuclear scaling. Rapid Chinese nuclear deployment would demonstrate feasibility of large-scale nuclear renaissance and influence global energy trajectories.

signals.text: Before end of 2027, at least $100 billion in private investment flows into nuclear power projects globally, per Bloomberg New Energy Finance annual investment report
signals.reasoning: Private capital commitment indicates market confidence in nuclear's economic viability and growth potential. This level of investment would signal serious private sector belief in nuclear renaissance, beyond just government support.

signals.text: By December 2026, nuclear power receives explicit classification as 'green' or 'sustainable' investment in EU Taxonomy and at least 2 other major financial jurisdictions' ESG frameworks
signals.reasoning: Regulatory classification drives massive institutional investment flows. Green classification would unlock pension funds, ESG mandates, and green bonds for nuclear, dramatically accelerating financing and deployment.

signals.text: Before January 2029, average construction time for new nuclear plants falls below 7 years globally, per IAEA construction time database
signals.reasoning: Construction speed directly impacts nuclear's ability to scale rapidly enough to influence 2050 energy mix. Faster builds reduce costs, improve economics, and enable nuclear to compete with the rapid deployment rates of renewables.

signals.text: By end of 2027, at least 5 countries reverse previous nuclear phase-out policies and announce new nuclear capacity targets, per official government energy policy statements
signals.reasoning: Policy reversals would signal a fundamental shift in nuclear acceptability and political feasibility. Countries reconsidering phase-outs indicates changing risk/benefit calculations that could enable broader nuclear renaissance.

signals.text: Before December 2028, nuclear fusion achieves net energy gain >1.5x in at least 2 different reactor designs, per peer-reviewed publications in Nature, Science, or Physical Review Letters
signals.reasoning: Fusion breakthroughs could dramatically accelerate nuclear timeline by offering ultimate clean baseload solution. Multiple successful demonstrations would shift long-term energy planning and potentially accelerate fission investment as a bridge technology.

scenarios.name: Battery-Powered Transition
scenarios.description: Breakthrough advances in battery technology create a storage revolution that enables massive renewable deployment. Grid-scale storage becomes economically viable, solving intermittency issues and allowing wind/solar to dominate the energy mix. Nuclear remains stagnant as batteries provide the reliability previously requiring baseload power.
key_drivers: Battery costs fall below $50/kWh enabling grid-scale storage
Massive battery deployment (>100 GWh annually) proves economic viability
Strong renewable policies with enforcement mechanisms
Nuclear expansion fails to materialize significantly
Grid infrastructure adapts to accommodate renewable + storage systems
scenarios.why_exclusive: This scenario requires battery technology to solve the intermittency problem, making nuclear expansion unnecessary. The 65-75% range cannot co-occur with nuclear renaissance scenarios that would push total clean energy higher, or with policy failure scenarios that would keep renewables lower.
mapped_signals: By December 31, 2027, lithium-ion battery pack costs fall below $50/kWh
By June 30, 2028, at least 100 GWh of new grid-scale battery storage capacity is deployed globally
By December 31, 2026, at least 5 major utilities announce grid-scale battery storage projects exceeding 1 GWh each
By December 2026, the US passes federal legislation mandating >50% renewable electricity by 2035
By June 2027, China's National Development and Reform Commission announces >$200B in additional renewable energy subsidies

indicator_bundle.Utility storage adoption: >5 major utilities with 1+ GWh projects by 2026
indicator_bundle.Policy implementation strength: Major economy renewable mandates >50% with enforcement

scenarios.name: Nuclear Renaissance
scenarios.description: Nuclear power experiences a dramatic comeback driven by cost reductions, faster construction, and policy support. SMRs achieve commercialization and new large plants prove economically competitive. Combined with renewables, nuclear provides the reliable baseload needed for deep decarbonization, pushing total clean energy share to the highest levels.
key_drivers: SMR technology achieves commercial viability and regulatory approval
Nuclear construction costs fall below $80/MWh making it competitive
Multiple countries reverse nuclear phase-out policies
Massive private investment ($100B+) flows into nuclear projects
Construction times improve to under 7 years enabling rapid deployment
scenarios.why_exclusive: This scenario requires nuclear to capture significant market share that would otherwise go to renewables + storage. The 75-85% range reflects nuclear + renewables together achieving maximum decarbonization. This cannot co-occur with battery-powered scenarios where nuclear remains minimal, or policy failure scenarios where overall clean energy deployment is constrained.
mapped_signals: Before January 2029, at least one Small Modular Reactor design receives full commercial operating license
Before December 2028, nuclear power costs fall below $80/MWh LCOE for new plants
By end of 2027, at least 5 countries reverse previous nuclear phase-out policies
Before end of 2027, at least $100 billion in private investment flows into nuclear power projects
Before January 2029, average construction time for new nuclear plants falls below 7 years globally

indicator_bundle.SMR commercialization: At least 1 SMR design licensed by 2029

scenarios.name: Policy-Driven Acceleration
scenarios.description: Unprecedented global policy coordination drives rapid renewable deployment through massive public investment, carbon pricing, and elimination of fossil fuel subsidies. Both battery storage and nuclear see moderate growth, but the primary driver is coordinated government action creating market conditions for all clean technologies to scale simultaneously.
key_drivers: G20 establishes binding international carbon price floor >$75/tonne
Global renewable investment reaches >$3 trillion annually with 70%+ government backing
Major economies eliminate fossil fuel subsidies worth >$50B annually
Strong enforcement mechanisms with penalties >$10B for non-compliance
International coordination through IMF lending conditions and trade policy
scenarios.why_exclusive: This scenario is defined by unprecedented policy coordination being the primary driver, rather than breakthrough technology in either batteries or nuclear. The 70-80% range reflects strong but not maximum deployment due to reliance on policy rather than pure economic competitiveness. Cannot co-occur with technology-led scenarios where policy plays secondary role.
mapped_signals: By June 2027, the G20 establishes a binding international carbon price floor of >$75/tonne
By January 2028, global renewable energy investment reaches >$3 trillion annually with >70% government-backed
By January 2028, >15 countries eliminate fossil fuel subsidies worth >$50B annually combined
By December 2025, the EU Carbon Border Adjustment Mechanism covers >80% of global trade value
By June 2027, the International Monetary Fund conditions >$100B in lending on renewable targets

indicator_bundle.Institutional leverage: IMF conditional lending >$100B tied to renewables by 2027

scenarios.name: Constrained Transition
scenarios.description: Clean energy deployment proceeds but faces significant constraints from policy implementation failures, technology bottlenecks, and economic headwinds. Neither battery costs nor nuclear deployment achieve breakthrough levels. Progress occurs but falls short of Paris targets due to coordination failures and competing priorities.
key_drivers: Battery costs plateau above breakthrough thresholds limiting storage deployment
Nuclear revival fails due to continued cost/construction time challenges
Policy implementation remains fragmented with weak enforcement
Private investment in clean energy remains limited relative to needs
Grid infrastructure and permitting create deployment bottlenecks
scenarios.why_exclusive: This scenario represents the failure of the breakthrough conditions in other scenarios. The 45-60% range reflects continued but constrained progress, incompatible with the technology breakthroughs or policy coordination that would drive higher outcomes. Represents a world where current trends continue without major accelerants.
mapped_signals: Failure of battery costs to reach $50/kWh threshold by 2027
Nuclear construction pipeline remains <200 GW by 2026
Less than 10 US states implement >80% renewable standards by 2026
Private nuclear investment remains <$100B globally by 2027
Global renewable investment stays <$3T annually through 2028

indicator_bundle.Policy enforcement strength: <20 US states with >80% renewable standards by 2026
indicator_bundle.Investment scale: Annual renewable investment <$2T with <50% government backing
indicator_bundle.Grid deployment rate: <50 GW annual battery storage additions globally by 2028

mece_reasoning: These scenarios are MECE because they partition the renewable energy outcome space along two key dimensions: (1) which technology breakthrough occurs (batteries vs nuclear vs neither) and (2) the strength of policy coordination. The outcome ranges are mutually exclusive: 45-60% (Constrained), 65-75% (Battery-Powered), 70-80% (Policy-Driven), and 75-85% (Nuclear Renaissance). Each scenario is defined by fundamentally different causal pathways that cannot simultaneously occur - you cannot have both a battery breakthrough that makes nuclear unnecessary AND a nuclear renaissance that captures market share from renewables. The Policy-Driven scenario occupies the middle-high range because it relies on coordination rather than breakthrough economics, while Constrained represents the continuation of current constraints without major breakthroughs or coordination.
